title: Swaffham Walks

nearby.description: Peddars Way and Norfolk Coast Path
Grime's Graves and Weeting Castle Walk

images.title: Eileen Henderson / Buttercross, Swaffham
images.caption: Buttercross, Swaffham. The Butter Cross in Swaffham's market place was built in 1783, and was paid for by the Earl of Orford. The figure on top of the dome represents the Roman goddess Ceres. In more modern times, the structure has been used as a bandstand.

images.title: Keith Evans / Shoemaker's lane
images.caption: Shoemaker's lane. Looking west along Shoemakers lane just to the east of the town. Just over the hill is Town Farm.

images.title: Keith Evans / Downhill track
images.caption: Downhill track. Forest track leading to a gated cross track near to Drymere Norfolk. The white blob just to the left of centre is a covered water tank

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Drymere Plantation
images.caption: Drymere Plantation. The forestry track proceeds north into the most northerly extension of the Thetford forest.

images.title: Bob Jones / Trees at Swaffham Heath
images.caption: Trees at Swaffham Heath

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / Cockley Cley Oak
images.caption: Cockley Cley Oak and the village green

description: This attractive market town is located in the Breckland District of Norfolk. There are some nice woodland trails to the west of the town, waterside walks through the Nar Valley to the north and miles of trails in the nearby Thetford Forest. The Peddars Way and Norfolk Coast Path National Trail also runs just to the east of the town, providing an opportunity to explore the surrounding countryside on a good waymarked trail. You may also recognise the town as the setting for the ITV1 series Kingdom, starring Stephen Fry. Kingdom's office is Oakleigh House, near the town square in what is known as Market Shipborough in the series. The town is also notable for its fine Georgian buildings and the very fine church of St Peter and Paul which dates from the medieval period. This walk takes you from the town to Swaffham Heath and Cockley Cley Wood, to the west of the town. The walk starts on the western side of the town where you can follow Shouldham Lane west towards Swaffham Heath. Follow the trails south and they will take you through woodland to Cockleycley Heath and Woods. Here you'll find the 12th century Norman chapel of St Mary's and a series of pretty lakes which are good ford birdwatching. After exploring the village the route returns to Swaffham on the same paths.
